collection.description: Frederick Douglass (c. 1817-1895) was an abolitionist, orator, and writer. In 1838, Douglass escaped from his Maryland enslaver, and over time became one of the most celebrated abolitionists and social reformers of the 19th century. This collection of 11 original documents and 6 copies contains Frederick Douglass’ bill of sale, correspondence, newspaper clippings, and additional copies of correspondence.
collection.title: Frederick Douglass Collection

project.desc: From a decentering whiteness standpoint, this project would add value to the body of available materials available online documenting Frederick Douglass. It would also contribute to available documentation such as manumission papers and bills of sale, which are being used in projects like enslaved.org to facilitate genealogical and historical research on individual enslaved people around the globe.
project.name: Slavery, Enslaved Persons, and Free Blacks in the Americas Collection / Frederick Douglas Collection / Wakefield Vellum Documents

ingest_project.title: P0380-Slavery, Enslaved Persons, and Free Blacks in the Americas Collection / Frederick Douglas Collection / Wakefield Vellum Documents

provenance: J.C. Shaffer, a Northwestern University patron, donated these materials to the university library. J.C. Shaffer's brother, W.H. Shaffer, purchased “certain papers” of Douglass from Benjamin Auld, son of Douglass’ enslaver, for $125 in 1896 (see Folder 2, Item 5). The bill of sale (Folder 1) and two letters from Frederick Douglass to the Aulds (Folder 2, Items 3-4) are referenced in an 1895 Indianapolis Journal article as being owned by Benjamin Auld and are also referenced in the letter from Auld to J.C. Shaffer (Folder 2, Item 6), along with the letters from Anna Richardson and Walter Lowrie (Folder 2, Items 1-2). It is unclear which items W.H. or J.C. Shaffer purchased directly from the Aulds.
series: Frederick Douglass Collection -- Frederick Douglass Correspondence, 1846-97
title: Helen Douglass to J.C. Shaffer. Cedar Hill, Anacostia, D.C. 2pp. Re: Frederick Douglass
library_unit: Charles Deering McCormick Library of Special Collections
